project.name: Ethnomusicology — Import & Catalog
project.description: Multi-source import screen and DJ metadata catalog for an LLM-powered DJ setlist platform

facets.name: Screen Inventory
facets.rationale: Maps the import screen, catalog view, and their states — everything downstream depends on knowing what surfaces exist
facets.locked_summary: Catalog-First: 1 primary screen (Track Catalog) + 1 secondary (Import Sheet overlay). Catalog is home base, import is a drawer/sheet action. Extensible for multiple sources and AI generation.
facets.decision_rationale: DJs browse far more than they import. The catalog is the product — import is one of many future actions (Beatport, SoundCloud, local MP3, AI setlist generation) that feed into it. Catalog-first architecture provides the right foundation for extensibility.

facets.name: Edge States
facets.rationale: Import failures, invalid URLs, empty catalogs, Beatport downtime — DJs need clear recovery paths during set prep
facets.locked_summary: Context-Rich: tailored edge states per situation. Empty catalog shows source cards. URL errors show valid examples. Errors reassure 'your tracks are safe.' Partial imports show per-track results with failure reasons. Shaped skeletons for loading.
facets.decision_rationale: Context-rich approach matches the catalog-first architecture. First impressions matter for the empty catalog, and per-track import details help DJs make informed decisions during set prep.

facets.name: Layout
facets.rationale: Import screen has tabs + URL input + progress; catalog has enriched tiles — spatial arrangement drives everything compositional
facets.locked_summary: Full-Width Crate: edge-to-edge track table with sortable columns (Title, Artist, BPM, Key, Genre, Source). 48px collapsed icon rail on left reserves space for future browser pane (Option C). No max-width — uses every pixel. DJ software density.
facets.decision_rationale: Right v1 discipline — ship the dense track table now, expand to browser pane (Option C) when content justifies the space. Rail is a subtle bridge, not a promise.

facets.name: Content Hierarchy
facets.rationale: DJs think in BPM and key, not artist and title — what gets emphasis on the track tile is the core design question

facets.name: Component Design
facets.rationale: Enriched track tile, source tabs, Camelot key chips, source badges, import controls — the building blocks of the feature

facets.name: Elevation & Shape
facets.rationale: Surface treatments for track tiles and metadata chips — Material 3 elevation applied to DJ-specific components

facets.name: Typography
facets.rationale: Track tile scannability across dozens of tracks — font sizes and weights for BPM, key, genre at a glance

facets.name: Color System
facets.rationale: Camelot key color-coding is the core differentiator — 24 keys mapped to tinted chips, plus source badge colors

facets.name: Density & Spacing
facets.rationale: DJs need to scan fast — catalog density is a feature. How many tracks visible at once, tile padding, chip spacing

facets.name: Accessibility
facets.rationale: Camelot colors need contrast checking, keyboard nav through catalog, screen reader labels for metadata chips
